results.headline: Review: ‘Childless,’ a Film of Connected Monologues, Stars Joe Mantegna
results.summary_short: The movie, written and directed by Charlie Levi, follows a group of Angelenos dealing with problems, among them the death of a child.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Childless

results.headline: Review: With ‘One Cut, One Life,’ Ed Pincus and Lucia Small Document His Illness
results.summary_short: In his final years, the documentary pioneer Ed Pincus joined with the filmmaker Lucia Small, to record his medical struggles and their own collaboration.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Cut, One Life

results.headline: Review: ‘Two Shots Fired,’ Martín Rejtman’s Absurdist Tale
results.summary_short: A teenager impulsively shoots himself in the head and stomach, and survives, in this tale full of shaggy-dog digressions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dos Disparos

results.display_title: Forbidden Films: The Hidden Legacy of Nazi Film
results.headline: Review: ‘Forbidden Films’ Details Nazi Propaganda
results.summary_short: This Felix Moeller film documents how the Third Reich was behind movies that incited and justified hatred.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forbidden Films: The Hidden Legacy of Nazi Film

results.display_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared
results.headline: Review: ‘The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared’
results.summary_short: This often droll Swedish movie is a new entry in the genre that might be called Old People Behaving Hilariously.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared

results.headline: Review: ‘Saint Laurent,’ Beautiful People, High Fashion and Career at Its Pinnacle
results.summary_short: This film by Bertrand Bonello offers an all-access look into the designer Yves Saint Laurent at work and after-hours with a perspective that is at once intimate and detached.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saint Laurent

results.headline: Review: ‘The Seven Five,’ a Documentary About a Corrupt New York Cop
results.summary_short: Tiller Russell’s documentary focuses on Michael Dowd, a Brooklyn police officer who in the late 1980s was earning $4,000 a week from illegal dealings with drug organizations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Seven Five

results.headline: Review: ‘Preggoland.’ It’s a Nice Place to Visit. Sort Of.
results.summary_short: Jacob Tierney’s comedy focuses on a single, childless and irresponsible woman who pretends to be pregnant after a mistaken assumption.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Preggoland

results.headline: Review: ‘Playing It Cool,’ with Chris Evans
results.summary_short: Cut loose from the flash-bang-wallop of the “Captain America” and “Avengers” franchises, Chris Evans seems lost.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Playing It Cool

results.headline: Review: ‘Noble,’ the Crusade of a Children’s Rights Activist
results.summary_short: The film follows Christina Noble, who emerged from a traumatic childhood in Dublin to build a foundation that helps thousands of children in Vietnam and Mongolia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noble

results.headline: Review: ‘Intrepido’ Follows an Italian From Job to Job
results.summary_short: In a land with high unemployment, a man is willing to do anything, for a time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of L' intrepido

results.headline: Review: In ‘The D Train,’ Jack Black and James Marsden in a Steamy Bromance
results.summary_short: In this bromantic comedy, Mr. Black’s character wants Mr. Marsden’s to attend their high school reunion, but he gets a great deal more.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Piku,’ Amitabh Bachchan Plays a Dad to Deepika Padukone
results.summary_short: A young career woman and her demanding, aging father bicker at home and on the road in this Hindi film directed by Shoojit Sircar.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Maggie,’ Arnold Schwarzenegger Faces Zombies
results.summary_short: The movie, about a virus that turns its victims into zombies, was directed by Henry Hobson.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Hot Pursuit,’ Sofia Vergara and Reese Witherspoon on the Run
results.summary_short: The women, one the wife of a criminal and the other a police officer, are thrown together by improbable circumstances in this buddy comedy.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Bravetown,’ a Bad Boy Redeems Himself Through D.J. Magic
results.summary_short: The film is part high school dance competition movie and part shameless flag-waver.

results.headline: Review: In ‘5 Flights Up,’ a Marriage of Morgan Freeman and Diane Keaton
results.summary_short: Mr. Freeman and Ms. Keaton play a Brooklyn couple who need to sell their fifth-floor walk-up. They find that in New York, real estate isn’t easy.

results.headline: Review: ‘1001 Grams,’ by the Norwegian Filmmaker Bent Hamer, Mixes Levity and Gravity
results.summary_short: Mr. Hamer is notable for his deadpan visual wit and his interest in odd jobs.

results.display_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story
results.headline: Review: ‘I Am Big Bird’ Tells Caroll Spinney’s Story
results.summary_short: This documentary includes anecdotes about Mr. Spinney’s 45-year run as the “Sesame Street” character.

results.headline: Review: Kristen Wiig as a Troubled Lottery Winner in ‘Welcome to Me’
results.summary_short: Ms. Wiig’s character decides to spend a major financial windfall on buying her own talk show in this dark comedy directed by Shira Piven.
